blog.name: writingfromkitchenator
blog.title: Kitchenator's Writers Blog
blog.description:
Hey everyone! Welcome to my writer's blog. All fanfic writing I use for practise for my own work, as well as just loving the worlds that they come from, I own none of the content bar my own characters. All original work is owned by me and under copyright. Please free to explore and don't hesitate to ever send me a message, I'm very easy going and would love to chat.

Middle Earth Requests: CLOSED

Supernatural Requests: CLOSED

Marvel Requests: CLOSED

title: Crowley ~ Arsonist’s Lullaby
body:
Arsonist’s Lullaby by Hozier

600 Followers Challenge!

Request be Anon.

Words: 1213

Crowley sat in a darkened corner of the bar alone, completely ignoring all the activities around him.  It wasn’t that he wanted to be here, but the truth was, he needed a place to think and have a drink, something that the throne room wasn’t going to provide, especially once his demons realised he was there.

He watched the golden liquid shift in his glass, catching in the small amounts of light that reached him, and while he knew he was procrastinating his own thoughts, he felt calmer than what he had in days.

He didn’t like being like this, didn’t like having things out of his control, and the worse thing about it all, he didn’t have anyone that he would dare even mention it too.

The door to the bar opened and for the first time since he sat down, he found his gaze wandering up. Almost instantly he regretted his decision, leaning as far back into the shadows as he could, for a moment forgetting that he could simply disappear.

You strode into the bar, flashing a smile at the bar keeper, Crowley watching half curious, half terrified at what you could possibly doing here.

You moved away after a few words and went and sat at your own table, letting Crowley relax in his spot but still not taking his eyes off of you and silently cursing himself.

Of all the places in the world that he could’ve picked, he had to walk into the one place that you happened to go to too.

He tried to put his attention back onto his glass, tried to get back into the nice state that he’d been in, but his gaze was drawn to you constantly, his only relief was when someone would come over and top up his glass.

Finally, he felt like he was winning his battle against you when he found his gaze locked on you once more and he found himself frozen in his chair.  There was someone talking to you and from what he could tell, you were lapping up the attention.

Crowley’s hand closed too hard around his glass and it broke, making him look at his hand with a frown, a few shards having broken his skin, blood mixing with had been left in his glass.

The bar keeper was halfway through coming over when Crowley was on his feet striding out of the pub, not wanting to stay in there a moment longer as his stomach twisted in knots.

He was just about in a place where he could safely teleport himself away when your voice stopped him.

“Crowley?”

He debated for a single moment whether he would turn around to face you or whether he would get himself out of there before he realised there wasn’t any point to even having that thought.

Pushing his annoyance aside, he turned to look at you with a grin.  “Hello love, didn’t realise you came out to places like this.”

You titled your head, having stopped several feet away from him, clearly trying to work out what was going on.  “Nor I, you. I thought a demon of your calibre would have better standards.”

Crowley shrugs it off. “They have the drink I like, who am I to say no.”

Burying your hands in your pockets against the chill in the air, you rock a little on your heels, breaking your gaze away.  “So…what was with what happened in there?”

“Just more unfortunate incidents from the incompetent fools I work with.”

You brought your gaze back to his and he knew that you didn’t believe him.  “Funny, didn’t think it’d be worth breaking a glass over.”

There was a pause between the two of you, sitting a little awkwardly in the air and you were both silently glad that there wasn’t anyone else around.

“You’ve dealt with more than your fair share of demons love, you know what they are like.”  Crowley tried to save the lie, but he knew by your strained smile that it was far too late for that.

“I do,” You said quietly. “But I also know enough that it’s not all bad.”

Crowley stares at you, taking a moment to register your words.  “We are the epitome of evil.”

“And yet a few of you still make the right choice from time to time.”

He blanches.

Sighing, you pull your jacket closer around you.  “Evil is too black and white Crowley, everything is much more complicated than that.” You pause.  “I…I’ll leave you to get back to your demons then.”

Crowley watched you go, his mind working much too quick for him to make sense of anything for a moment before he rashly made a decision.

“Y/N, wait.”

You stopped and looked back at him.

“I…” He honestly wasn’t sure what to say and he hated it.

“You don’t have to say anything Crowley.” You said softly, turning away again.

He teleports himself in front of you, making you take a cautious step back.

He holds his hands up quickly.  “I…I’m sorry, I don’t really know how to do this.”

You frowned.  “You don’t know how to do…”

Crowley sighs.  “To say thank you.”

A smile tugged at your lips. “You don’t know how to say thank you?”

He purses his lips. “I’m trying here, okay? This…this isn’t something that’s usually part of my day to day.”

You tilt your head.  “Okay…but why are you thanking me?”

Crowley thinks, forcing himself to take it slower this time, getting his thoughts in order.  “My peace has always depended on all the ashes in my wake.  You’ve been changing that.”

“I have?”

He nods slowly. “You…you’ve changed…me.  A lot.  To be honest I can’t say I’m too happy about it but there’s also not really anything I can do about it or want to do about it.”

Biting your lip a little and looking at him a little confused, you give an unsure smile. “You’re welcome?  I guess?”

Crowley sighs, frustrated at himself.  “Darling…I’m trying…I’m trying to say that you’ve made me better…that I want to do more for you.”  He drags his gaze away from yours.  “You’re the only one I’ve ever met that’s actually given a damn.”

“You’re my friend Crowley, of course I give a damn.”  You said. “It’s not…it’s not something that’s ever felt wrong, if that’s what you needed to hear?”

Pausing, he glances at you, finding the gentility in your gaze that he’d came to know too well and make his chest ache.

He nods before he says anything else foolish.  “Thank you.”

Smiling, you pat his arm as you walk past.  “Anytime Crowley, happy to help where I can.”  He watches you start to walk away, but turn back to face him.  “Just…maybe don’t think so much?  It seems to stop you saying what you actually want to.” You wave back at him.  “Don’t let the demons get you down Crowley!”

Crowley watches you go, watches as you wander past the bar but without going back in and he lets out a breathe that he didn’t realise he’d been holding.

Maybe, one day, he would take you up on that offer and say all that he wanted to say, but for now, this was enough.

Request be Anon.

Words: 1213

He watched the golden liquid shift in his glass, catching in the small amounts of light that reached him, and while he knew he was procrastinating his own thoughts, he felt calmer than what he had in days.

He didn’t like being like this, didn’t like having things out of his control, and the worse thing about it all, he didn’t have anyone that he would dare even mention it too.

He teleports himself in front of you, making you take a cautious step back.

He holds his hands up quickly.  “I…I’m sorry, I don’t really know how to do this.”

You frowned.  “You don’t know how to do…”

Crowley sighs.  “To say thank you.”

A smile tugged at your lips. “You don’t know how to say thank you?”

He purses his lips. “I’m trying here, okay? This…this isn’t something that’s usually part of my day to day.”

You tilt your head.  “Okay…but why are you thanking me?”

Crowley thinks, forcing himself to take it slower this time, getting his thoughts in order.  “My peace has always depended on all the ashes in my wake.  You’ve been changing that.”

“I have?”

He nods slowly. “You…you’ve changed…me.  A lot.  To be honest I can’t say I’m too happy about it but there’s also not really anything I can do about it or want to do about it.”

Biting your lip a little and looking at him a little confused, you give an unsure smile. “You’re welcome?  I guess?”

Crowley sighs, frustrated at himself.  “Darling…I’m trying…I’m trying to say that you’ve made me better…that I want to do more for you.”  He drags his gaze away from yours.  “You’re the only one I’ve ever met that’s actually given a damn.”

“You’re my friend Crowley, of course I give a damn.”  You said. “It’s not…it’s not something that’s ever felt wrong, if that’s what you needed to hear?”

Pausing, he glances at you, finding the gentility in your gaze that he’d came to know too well and make his chest ache.

He nods before he says anything else foolish.  “Thank you.”

Smiling, you pat his arm as you walk past.  “Anytime Crowley, happy to help where I can.”  He watches you start to walk away, but turn back to face him.  “Just…maybe don’t think so much?  It seems to stop you saying what you actually want to.” You wave back at him.  “Don’t let the demons get you down Crowley!”

summary: The Enemy, of course. But an enemy for six thousand years now, which made him a sort of friend.

Things...People...
Feelings
blog.description: This is a Supernatural fan blog with the occasional other fannish post thrown into the mix. Jeremy Carver, Phil Sgriccia, Jerry Wanek and Serge Ladouceur are my heroes, whereas S12 is my personal nightmare from which I'm still hoping to wake up. I'm a multi-shipper and feminist, currently trying hard not to turn into a bitter Dean!girl.

Priorities, Crowley has them.

1. Bicker with Dean.

2. Protect precious suit from rain.

3. Not get hit by car.

4. Not get captured by evil ex-minions.

…

…

…

title: The Only Exception
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2yeFUdb

by randomfandomimagine

Requested by anon:
Can you do an imagine for Castiel from SPN for a Soulmate!Au where the first words they speak to each other is written on their wrist? So reader is a demon who is extremely well-known by both angels and demons as the most fearsome demon. But when Cas meets them, reader is actually somehow a pretty sweet demon who has no control over their fire power and just sets everything on fire by accident? Cas and reader meet and reader accidentally sets his coat on fire the moment they meet?

Words: 2364, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

Series: Part 13 of Imagines

  • Fandoms: Supernatural

summary: “There were people who called themselves Satanists who made Crowley squirm. It wasn’t just the things they did, it was the way...
body:
“There were people who called themselves Satanists who made Crowley squirm. It wasn’t just the things they did, it was the way they blamed it all on Hell. They’d come up with some stomach-churning idea that no demon could have thought of in a thousand years, some dark and mindless unpleasantness that only a fully-functioning human brain could conceive, then shout, “The Devil Made Me Do It” and get the sympathy of the court when the whole point was that the Devil hardly ever made anyone do anything. He didn’t have to. That was what some humans found hard to understand. Hell wasn’t a major reservoir of evil, any more than Heaven, in Crowley’s opinion, was a fountain of goodness; they were just sides in the great cosmic chess game. Where you found the real McCoy, the real grace and the real heart-stopping evil, was right inside the human mind.”

Good omens, Neil Gaiman.

reblog.comment:

They’d come up with some stomach-churning idea that no demon could have thought of in a thousand years, some dark and mindless unpleasantness that only a fully-functioning human brain could conceive, then shout, “The Devil Made Me Do It” and get the sympathy of the court when the whole point was that the Devil hardly ever made anyone do anything. He didn’t have to. That was what some humans found hard to understand. Hell wasn’t a major reservoir of evil, any more than Heaven, in Crowley’s opinion, was a fountain of goodness; they were just sides in the great cosmic chess game. Where you found the real McCoy, the real grace and the real heart-stopping evil, was right inside the human mind.”

Good omens, Neil Gaiman.

trail.content_raw:

They’d come up with some stomach-churning idea that no demon could have thought of in a thousand years, some dark and mindless unpleasantness that only a fully-functioning human brain could conceive, then shout, “The Devil Made Me Do It” and get the sympathy of the court when the whole point was that the Devil hardly ever made anyone do anything. He didn’t have to. That was what some humans found hard to understand. Hell wasn’t a major reservoir of evil, any more than Heaven, in Crowley’s opinion, was a fountain of goodness; they were just sides in the great cosmic chess game. Where you found the real McCoy, the real grace and the real heart-stopping evil, was right inside the human mind.”

Good omens, Neil Gaiman.
trail.content:
“There were people who called themselves Satanists who made Crowley squirm. It wasn’t just the things they did, it was the way they blamed it all on Hell. They’d come up with some stomach-churning idea that no demon could have thought of in a thousand years, some dark and mindless unpleasantness that only a fully-functioning human brain could conceive, then shout, “The Devil Made Me Do It” and get the sympathy of the court when the whole point was that the Devil hardly ever made anyone do anything. He didn’t have to. That was what some humans found hard to understand. Hell wasn’t a major reservoir of evil, any more than Heaven, in Crowley’s opinion, was a fountain of goodness; they were just sides in the great cosmic chess game. Where you found the real McCoy, the real grace and the real heart-stopping evil, was right inside the human mind.”

Good omens, Neil Gaiman.
